questions.prompt: A 470Ω resistor has 12V across it. What current flows through it?
questions.explanation: Use I = V/R = 12V / 470Ω = 0.0255A = 25.5mA. Remember to convert to milliamps at the end!

questions.prompt: A resistor dissipates 5W when carrying 0.5A. What is its resistance?
questions.explanation: Use P = I²R, so R = P/I² = 5W/(0.5A)² = 5/0.25 = 20Ω. When you have P and I, this is the fastest formula!

questions.prompt: Two resistors (6kΩ and 3kΩ) in series across 18V. What's the voltage across the 3kΩ resistor?
questions.explanation: V_out = V_in × (R₂/(R₁+R₂)) = 18V × (3k/(6k+3k)) = 18V × (3/9) = 18V × (1/3) = 6V. The smaller resistor gets proportionally less voltage.

questions.prompt: A resistor has conductance G = 0.02S. What is its resistance?
questions.explanation: R = 1/G = 1/0.02 = 50Ω. Conductance and resistance are reciprocals: G = 1/R

questions.prompt: Which of these is equivalent to 2.2kΩ?
questions.explanation: kilo (k) means ×1000, so 2.2kΩ = 2.2 × 1000Ω = 2200Ω. This is a very common source of errors!

questions.prompt: A 100Ω resistor has 10V across it. How much power does it dissipate?
questions.explanation: P = V²/R = (10V)²/100Ω = 100/100 = 1W. When you have V and R, use P = V²/R!

questions.prompt: Two resistors (10Ω and 20Ω) in series with a 6V battery. What current flows?
questions.explanation: R_total = R₁ + R₂ = 10Ω + 20Ω = 30Ω. Then I = V/R_total = 6V/30Ω = 0.2A. In series, resistances add!

questions.prompt: What does it mean for a resistor to be 'linear'?
options: The V-I graph is a straight line through the origin
The current is constant regardless of voltage
Power dissipation is linear with voltage
questions.correctAnswer: The V-I graph is a straight line through the origin
questions.explanation: Linearity means the relationship between cause (Voltage) and effect (Current) is proportional, i.e., I ∝ V. Graphically, this is a straight line passing through (0,0).

questions.prompt: An open circuit is equivalent to a resistor with what value?
questions.explanation: An open circuit allows NO current to flow (I=0) regardless of voltage. From R=V/I, as I approaches 0, R approaches infinity.

questions.prompt: Why is a resistor connected in series with an LED?
options: To limit the current and prevent burnout
questions.correctAnswer: To limit the current and prevent burnout
questions.explanation: LEDs are non-linear devices that will draw excessive current if connected directly to a voltage source above their forward voltage. The resistor limits this current to a safe value (e.g., 20mA).
